crimeLevel.description: The prevalence of crime in society.

policePresence.description: The extent of law enforcement activity.

judicialStrictness.description: Severity of laws and judicial enforcement.

stateSurveillance.description: The level of state monitoring of civilians.

civilLiberties.description: The extent of personal freedoms and rights.

enum: None (No organized crime presence, strong legal enforcement)
Minimal (Small criminal groups, low impact on society)
Low (Localized criminal syndicates, limited political influence)
Moderate (Established mafia/cartel operations, some corruption ties)
High (Widespread organized crime, significant corruption in law enforcement)
Severe (Mafia/cartels influence government policy and economy)
Extreme (State deeply intertwined with criminal networks, government largely compromised)
organizedCrimeInfluence.description: The level of influence organized crime groups such as mafias, cartels, and terrorist organizations have over national operations.

enum: None (Zero corruption, total transparency in policing and judiciary)
Minimal (Occasional cases of low-level bribery, swiftly punished)
Low (Some corrupt officers, but does not affect major operations)
Moderate (Widespread bribery at lower levels, occasional high-level cases)
High (Judiciary and police frequently compromised, corruption scandals common)
Severe (Bribery is expected at all levels, judicial rulings influenced by money or power)
Extreme (Law enforcement and courts are fully corrupt, no meaningful justice system)
corruptionInLawEnforcement.description: The extent of bribery and misconduct within the police and judiciary, from rare cases to complete system collapse.

enum: Total Independence (Completely autonomous judiciary, free from political interference)
High Independence (Minor political influence, but largely neutral courts)
Moderate Independence (Some government pressure, but courts still uphold legal standards)
Limited Independence (Judicial rulings often politically motivated, some impartiality remains)
Low Independence (Frequent government interference, opposition cases rarely fair)
Severe Interference (Judiciary largely a tool of the ruling regime, no real independence)
Nonexistent (Courts serve only the regime, no legal autonomy, show trials common)
judicialIndependence.description: The degree of autonomy courts have from government and political interference, ranging from total independence to complete subservience.

enum: None (Complete societal harmony, no unrest or protests)
Minimal (Rare, peaceful demonstrations with no major impact)
Low (Occasional protests, generally non-violent and well-controlled)
Moderate (Regular protests and strikes, minor disruptions to daily life)
High (Widespread demonstrations, some violent clashes with law enforcement)
Severe (Riots and uprisings, frequent mass protests, risk of regional instability)
Extreme (Nationwide unrest, constant strikes, risk of civil war or revolution)
civilUnrestLevel.description: The frequency and intensity of protests, strikes, and riots, ranging from peaceful demonstrations to widespread societal upheaval.

enum: Completely Illiterate (Less than 10% of population can read and write)
Extremely Low Literacy (10-30% literacy, widespread educational underdevelopment)
Low Literacy (30-50% literacy, significant barriers to education)
Moderate Literacy (50-70% literacy, improving but still major gaps)
Above Average Literacy (70-85% literacy, strong basic education system)
High Literacy (85-95% literacy, functional literacy for most of the population)
Very High Literacy (95-99% literacy, well-developed education system)
Universal Literacy (99-100% literacy, fully literate population)
literacyRate.description: The percentage of the population that can read and write, representing the overall effectiveness of the education system.

enum: Extreme Unemployment (Less than 20% of population employed, economic collapse)
Very High Unemployment (20-35% unemployment, severe economic distress)
High Unemployment (10-20% unemployment, weak job market)
Moderate Unemployment (7-10% unemployment, economic struggles but some stability)
Balanced Employment (5-7% unemployment, considered normal economic function)
Strong Employment (3-5% unemployment, robust job market)
Very High Employment (1-3% unemployment, nearly full employment)
Full Employment (0-1% unemployment, extremely strong labor market)
employmentRate.description: General employment statistics, including unemployment levels and overall labor market health.

enum: Completely Rigid (Social class is entirely fixed, no upward mobility possible)
Extremely Low Mobility (Only extreme wealth or privilege allows upward movement)
Low Mobility (Difficult to change social class, limited economic opportunities)
Moderate Mobility (Possible but difficult, education and connections are key)
Above Average Mobility (A strong middle class, some opportunities for advancement)
High Mobility (People can advance through merit and education, economic flexibility)
Very High Mobility (Class mobility is common, strong economic and educational access)
Equal Opportunity (Class barriers are nearly non-existent, fully meritocratic society)
socialMobility.description: The ease of upward economic and social movement, determining how accessible higher living standards are to the population.

populationSize.description: The overall population size of the nation.

populationGrowth.description: The rate of population growth or decline.

ageStructure.description: The overall distribution of age groups in the population.

urbanizationLevel.description: The proportion of people living in urban areas.

birthRate.description: The rate of births per capita.

dominanceLevel.description: The relative presence of an ethnic group in the country.

ethnicComposition.description: The ethnic breakdown of the population.

dominanceLevel.description: The relative presence of a religion in the country.

religiousComposition.description: The religious breakdown of the population.

enum: Extreme Inequality (Top 1% controls nearly all wealth, mass poverty)
Severe Disparity (Wealth concentrated among elites, little middle class)
High Inequality (Large wealth gap, lower classes struggle economically)
Moderate Inequality (Wealth unevenly distributed, but some middle-class security)
Balanced Distribution (Significant middle class, but income gaps still present)
Low Inequality (Wealth is fairly distributed, economic mobility is high)
Near-Equal Distribution (Minimal wealth gap, strong social safety nets)
Full Economic Parity (Completely even wealth distribution, no class divisions)
wealthDistribution.description: The level of economic inequality, measuring how wealth is distributed across different social classes.

enum: None (Government does not provide financial support to any industry)
Agriculture (Farming, food production, and rural development subsidies)
Energy (Fossil fuels, nuclear, or renewable energy industry support)
Technology & Innovation (R&D, AI, space programs, high-tech subsidies)
Healthcare (Public hospitals, pharmaceutical industries, medical research)
Education (Public schools, universities, research institutions funding)
Transportation (Infrastructure, public transit, road and railway development)
Defense & Military (Subsidized military-industrial complex, arms production)
Social Welfare (Basic income, unemployment support, housing assistance)
Financial Sector (Bank bailouts, monetary policy intervention)
Cultural & Media (Arts, entertainment, state-run media, cultural programs)
sector.description: The economic sector receiving government financial support.

enum: None (No subsidies provided in this sector)
Negligible (Symbolic funding, primarily for political reasons)
Minimal (Only essential subsidies, limited impact on sector growth)
Low (Targeted financial aid for select industries or regions)
Moderate (Steady government support, incentives for development)
Above Average (Significant funding, sector receives competitive advantages)
High (Government plays an active role in sector expansion and innovation)
Very High (Industry depends heavily on government financial support)
Extreme (Government dominance in funding, near-total reliance on subsidies)
State-Controlled (Fully government-funded and operated, subsidies ensure sector survival)
subsidyLevel.description: The extent to which the government financially supports this sector, ranging from symbolic assistance to full state control.

governmentSubsidies.description: The key areas of the economy receiving direct financial support from the government, along with the scale of subsidies provided.

enum: None (Fully privatized economy, no government-owned businesses)
Minimal (Few state-run enterprises, mostly privatized sectors)
Limited (State controls key sectors like energy and infrastructure)
Moderate (Government owns major industries, but private sector thrives)
Significant (State dominates strategic sectors, private businesses restricted)
Heavy (Most industries under government control, limited privatization)
Total State Economy (No private sector, fully government-run economy)
stateOwnedEnterprises.description: The proportion of the economy directly controlled by state-owned enterprises.

enum: None (No worker protections, exploitative labor conditions, no unions allowed)
Minimal (Weak labor laws, few protections, unionizing discouraged)
Weak (Low minimum wages, long working hours, little job security)
Moderate (Basic worker rights, some protections, limited union power)
Balanced (Strong worker protections, union influence present but regulated)
High (Strict labor laws, guaranteed wages, strong collective bargaining)
Very High (Highly protected workforce, strong unions, universal worker benefits)
Absolute (Workers have total job security, government-enforced equality in pay and conditions)
laborRightsProtections.description: The strength of worker rights and labor protections, ranging from exploitative conditions to full employment security.

enum: Hyperinflation (Completely unstable, rapid devaluation, economic collapse)
Severe Instability (Frequent crashes, inflation or deflation out of control)
High Volatility (Unstable exchange rates, unpredictable market fluctuations)
Moderate Volatility (Regular inflation, but overall controlled)
Relatively Stable (Occasional fluctuations, but strong financial policies)
Stable (Predictable currency value, backed by strong monetary policy)
Highly Stable (Trusted global reserve currency, minimal inflation)
Absolute Stability (Perfectly controlled, no fluctuation, full government control over valuation)
currencyStability.description: The volatility and trustworthiness of the national currency, ranging from hyperinflation to full economic control.

taxPolicy.description: Broad tax policy classification for corporate and income taxation.

enum: Fully Public (100% government-funded, no private education exists)
Overwhelmingly Public (90%+ public school enrollment, private education rare)
Majority Public (75-90% public enrollment, private schools for elite classes)
Balanced (50-75% public enrollment, private schools widely available)
Majority Private (25-50% public enrollment, private education dominates secondary and tertiary levels)
Overwhelmingly Private (10-25% public enrollment, public schools underfunded and rare)
Fully Private (0-10% public enrollment, education entirely privatized or voucher-based)
privateVsPublicEducation.description: The ratio of students attending public vs. private schools, indicating the level of government involvement in education.

enum: Negligible (Less than 5% of students advance to higher education)
Very Low (5-15% enrollment, higher education is rare and elitist)
Low (15-30% enrollment, access is limited by cost or policy)
Moderate (30-50% enrollment, university education becoming common)
Above Average (50-65% enrollment, higher education widely accessible)
Very High (80-95% enrollment, tertiary education is the norm)
Universal (95-100% enrollment, nearly all students pursue higher education)
higherEducationEnrollment.description: The percentage of students advancing to tertiary education, measuring accessibility and cultural emphasis on higher education.

enum: None (No vocational or technical education system exists)
Minimal (Scattered trade schools, highly informal training)
Limited (Basic trade programs, low government support)
Moderate (Established vocational system, but lacks prestige)
Strong (Vocational education widely available and respected)
Highly Developed (Integrated technical training with strong industry partnerships)
Elite (Advanced technical institutions, globally recognized certification programs)
vocationalTechnicalTraining.description: The availability and prestige of vocational and technical education programs, including trade schools and apprenticeships.

enum: None (No major universities or research centers exist)
Minimal (Few institutions, underfunded and low impact)
Limited (Some recognized universities, little global influence)
Moderate (Growing research sector, occasional major discoveries)
Strong (Well-funded universities, regular contributions to global research)
Highly Developed (Major research institutions, significant innovation output)
World-Class (Leading research hubs, driving technological and scientific progress)
researchInstitutions.description: The presence and quality of universities and research centers, influencing innovation and academic contributions.

educationQuality.description: Overall quality and effectiveness of the education system.

fundingLevel.description: The level of financial investment in education infrastructure and programs.

STEMDevelopment.description: The extent of funding and emphasis on STEM (Science, Technology, Engineering, and Mathematics) education.

total.description: Overall level of annual energy production.

fossilFuels.description: Relative level of energy from fossil fuels.

nuclear.description: Relative level of energy from nuclear sources.

hydro.description: Relative level of energy from hydropower.

wind.description: Relative level of energy from wind power.

solar.description: Relative level of energy from solar power.

breakdownBySource.description: A categorical breakdown of energy sources.

energyProduction.description: Overall and per-source levels of energy production, represented by enums.

enum: Severe Water Scarcity (Extreme shortages, unreliable access, crisis-level management)
High Water Stress (Frequent shortages, high reliance on imports or desalination)
Moderate Water Stress (Seasonal shortages, some supply vulnerabilities)
Stable Supply (Reliable water access, but future risks exist)
High Water Security (Well-managed resources, no major shortages)
Abundant Water Resources (Plentiful freshwater, surplus available for export)
waterSecurity.description: The stability and availability of freshwater resources for civilian, agricultural, and industrial use.

enum: Extreme Food Insecurity (Widespread hunger, famine conditions, total dependence on aid)
Severe Shortages (Regular food crises, high reliance on imports, malnutrition widespread)
Moderate Deficiency (Insufficient domestic production, significant food imports required)
Self-Sufficient (Meets domestic demand, but imports certain essential goods)
Surplus Producer (Exports food products, strong agricultural base)
Food Superpower (Dominates global food supply, vast agricultural production capabilities)
foodSecurity.description: The level of self-sufficiency and reliance on food imports, ranging from famine conditions to agricultural dominance.

enum: None (No known rare earth deposits, fully dependent on imports)
Negligible (Minimal extraction, heavily reliant on foreign sources)
Limited (Small-scale mining operations, unable to meet industrial demand)
Moderate (Self-sufficient supply, but reliant on some imports)
High (Significant extraction capacity, strong domestic supply chain)
Strategic Producer (One of the global leaders in rare earth mineral production)
Dominant Supplier (Controls majority of global rare earth production, critical to supply chains)
rareEarthMineralExtraction.description: The availability and control over critical rare earth minerals, essential for high-tech industries.

enum: Fully Dependent (100% reliant on energy imports, no domestic production)
Highly Dependent (Majority of energy needs met through imports)
Moderately Dependent (Significant domestic production, but still relies on imports)
Self-Sufficient (Energy needs met domestically, little reliance on imports)
Energy Surplus (Produces more energy than needed, exports surplus)
Energy Superpower (Globally dominant energy producer, major exporter)
energyDependence.description: The level of reliance on foreign energy imports versus domestic production capacity.

enum: No Regulations (No environmental protections, unchecked exploitation of resources)
Minimal Efforts (Weak regulations, environmental degradation widespread)
Moderate Protections (Basic laws in place, but enforcement is weak)
Sustainable Policies (Environmental protections actively enforced, moderate sustainability efforts)
Strong Conservation Efforts (Proactive government initiatives for environmental sustainability)
Global Environmental Leader (Highly stringent environmental policies, driving international sustainability efforts)
environmentalProtectionPolicies.description: The extent of government policies regarding sustainability, environmental regulations, and resource conservation.

renewableEnergyPercentage.description: Approximate share of renewable energy in total production.

oilProcurement.description: General level of daily oil procurement.

oilProduction.description: Estimated daily crude oil production levels, measured in millions of barrels per day (bpd). Reflects the nation's role in global energy markets.

healthcareQuality.description: Overall quality and effectiveness of the healthcare system.

fundingLevel.description: The level of financial investment in healthcare infrastructure and services.

publicHealthEffectiveness.description: The efficiency and impact of public health initiatives, including disease prevention, vaccination, and emergency response.

enum: Severe Housing Crisis (Extreme shortages, overcrowding, homelessness widespread)
High Shortage (Housing unaffordable or inaccessible for most of the population)
Moderate Shortage (High demand, rising prices, some housing gaps remain)
Balanced (Housing supply meets demand, affordable options exist for most)
Above Average Availability (Stable housing market, variety of affordable options)
High Availability (Accessible, affordable housing, well-developed urban planning)
Housing Surplus (Excess housing supply, low costs, easy accessibility for all)
housingQualityAvailability.description: The affordability and accessibility of housing, from severe shortages to surplus availability.

enum: Nonexistent (No public transit infrastructure, full reliance on private transport)
Minimal (Limited coverage, unreliable service, poorly maintained vehicles)
Basic (Public transport exists but is slow, inefficient, or lacks coverage)
Moderate (Functioning transit system, but overcrowding or inefficiencies present)
Well-Developed (Extensive transit coverage, reliable service in urban centers)
Highly Efficient (High-speed, well-integrated transit network, strong ridership)
World-Class (Seamless, high-tech transit system, affordable and widely used)
publicTransportEfficiency.description: The strength and efficiency of national and urban public transportation networks.

enum: Nonexistent (No paved roads, transportation infrastructure undeveloped)
Severely Underdeveloped (Basic roads exist, but poor maintenance and coverage)
Poor (Limited highways, traffic congestion, infrastructure deterioration common)
Moderate (Growing highway system, but bottlenecks and aging roads exist)
Well-Developed (Extensive, well-maintained highways, efficient road networks)
Highly Advanced (Modernized highways, high-speed road systems, minimal congestion)
World-Class (Smart infrastructure, automated traffic control, near-zero congestion)
roadHighwayDevelopment.description: The overall condition and efficiency of major road and highway networks.

enum: Nonexistent (No airports or seaports, full reliance on land transport)
Minimal (Small regional facilities, no major international trade capabilities)
Moderate (Functioning but congested or inefficient facilities, growing trade volume)
Well-Developed (Reliable air and sea trade infrastructure, modernized ports and hubs)
Highly Advanced (Major global trade hubs, seamless logistics and transport systems)
World-Class (Cutting-edge logistics, high-capacity trade infrastructure, major player in global transport)
airportPortInfrastructure.description: The level of development in air and sea trade facilities, affecting trade efficiency.

enum: Extremely Vulnerable (No emergency response capacity, catastrophic losses in disasters)
Highly Unprepared (Limited response capability, infrastructure collapses in crises)
Moderately Unprepared (Basic disaster management, but severe vulnerabilities remain)
Moderately Prepared (Some disaster resilience, but response efficiency inconsistent)
Well-Prepared (Effective emergency planning, trained personnel, strong infrastructure)
Highly Resilient (Strong disaster resilience, rapid response capacity, minimal disruption)
World-Class Preparedness (Near-invulnerable to disasters, best global response systems)
disasterPreparedness.description: The nationâ€™s capacity to withstand and recover from natural disasters, from extreme vulnerability to world-class preparedness.

urbanizationLevel.description: Degree of urbanization, representing the proportion of the population living in urban areas.

transportationInfrastructure.description: The overall level of development in transportation infrastructure, including roads, rail, airports, and ports.

enum: Basic Telegraph System (Manual switchboards, wired Morse code transmission)
Basic Landline (Rotary dial phones, operator-assisted calls)
Early Radio Broadcast (Shortwave and AM radio, limited two-way communication)
Advanced Radio Networks (Encrypted military radio, early frequency-hopping technology)
Early Microwave Relay (WWII-era military radar and radio relay stations)
Cold War-Era Landline (Automated telephone switching, copper wire infrastructure)
Basic Mobile Telephony (Analog cellular networks, early radio car phones)
2G Mobile (Digital voice transmission, basic SMS capabilities)
3G Mobile (Early internet browsing, moderate data speeds, voice calling)
4G LTE (High-speed mobile broadband, advanced wireless services)
5G Networks (Ultra-fast internet speeds, low latency, IoT integration)
Satellite-Based Communication (Global satellite phone networks, remote internet access)
Quantum Communications (Theoretically unbreakable encryption, quantum entanglement data transfer)
technologyLevel.description: The highest level of communication technology available in the country, ranging from early telegraphy to advanced quantum communication.

enum: Limited to Military and Government (Restricted, high-level use only)
Major Cities Only (Urban telephone and radio networks, rural areas lacking service)
Urban and Industrial Centers (Expanding coverage, but limited to economic hubs)
Widespread but Uneven (Decentralized telephone networks, some isolated regions lacking service)
Nationwide Landline Coverage (Copper wire telephone systems spanning most of the country)
Early Wireless Networks (Limited radio and early mobile coverage in select areas)
Expanding Mobile Network (Broad but inconsistent cellular coverage, dependent on technology)
Near-Universal Coverage (High-density telecommunications infrastructure in most regions)
Global Integration (International fiber-optic networks, satellite-linked global communication)
Total Connectivity (Near-instant, ultra-secure global communication infrastructure, including remote regions)
reach.description: The overall accessibility and reach of communication technology, from localized urban networks to full national and global coverage.

communicationInfrastructure.description: The state of telecommunications and internet infrastructure, combining technology and reach.
